text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Nils from
album spaces this is the latest
full-length LP from German pianist and
composer Nils Frahm hope I'm pronouncing
his name correctly this may be the first
time you're hearing of him but he is a
seasoned musician with numerous releases
under his belt so on this LP Nils
essentially does what many musicians do
they have a pretty sizable back
catalogue he puts out a live album and
because this is a live LP it's not like
Nils is pushing outside of those
minimalist and modern classical styles
that fans are used to actually quite a
bit material on this thing lands on
previous LPS like the bells and felt but
he goes into spaces with the mission and
for me that seems to be that he wants to
put the electrifying and pretty moving
magic of his live performances to tape
and in the process transform a lot of
these songs the song said and done alone
almost triples its length on this album
and if songs on this thing aren't being
stretched out they're being mashed into
massive medleys that span past 10 11 15
minutes on the song hammers you can even
hear what I assume is Nils manically
moaning along to the lead melodies that
he's playing which are really simple but
also beautiful and powerful and sort of
sit atop these speedily played piano
arpeggios that sort of serve as the
foundation of the song and even though
the general tone and the vibe of the
pianos here do give off a somewhat
new-age esque vibe on this live album
occasionally I do think that Nils is far
too spontaneous and gritty to be lumped
in such a category the entire album
itself even begins with an intentional
hiccup on the 1-minute track and aborted
beginning now even though this LP sticks
very wholly to solo piano compositions
it does have enough variety on it to
keep me engaged for most of this thing
like the song says which is this really
wonderful progressive synthesizer
Odyssey I'd expect from someone like
Vangelis but this track doesn't just
sound like another artist it also sounds
like
the sensation of being weightless it
sounds like the stars
sounds like interplanetary travel
following this track is the song said
and done which at its foundation has the
sustained piano notes just ringing very
rhythmically over and over and over it's
hypnotic and it's very simple
foundations like this that are the basis
for many songs on here and on top of
these rhythmic patterns Mills will drop
a very simple but pretty lead melody or
some very grand or glorious piano chords
and even though many of these tracks may
seem very repetitive and cyclical within
a given moment focus is never lost on
where the song is moving next like at
the 3-minute mark on this track we're
all of a sudden this entirely different
chord introduces itself ringing along
with the singular piano notes for
beautiful harmony and at the five-minute
mark on this track the amount of piano
notes ringing out with this sustain
seems to have increased to the point
where it sounds like I'm listening to
dozens of bells ringing all at once the
song is cluttered but it's wonderfully
uplifting and there's a very somber
piano piece finishing this track out as
well that's beautiful
but not every tone down moment on this
LP moves me like the song went missing
which I actually found to be kind of
nondescript I prefer moments on this
thing like familiar which has a much
Moody or melody and one that I think is
a lot more memorable and the track
improvisation for coughs and the
cellphone has a really dreary edge to
Ross's harmonium is another one of the
softer tracks on here the final track on
this entire thing and even though the
harmonium the tone of this song and the
really beautiful chords make it stick
out the abrupt fade that ends up
finishing this song off makes it a
pretty lackluster closer and makes me
feel like this album is is more of a
compilation of recordings live
recordings as opposed to a wholly
conceived project or album so there
definitely are some underwhelming spots
for me on this LP even if it doesn't
seem like it's a big deal because these
songs are consistently some of the
shortest on the album but I'm sort of
torn on this thing sometimes because
there are tracks on here that are in
credibly mountainous in their ambition
and their beauty like the the medley on
here for Peter toilet brushes and more
the song has all bees shimmering synth
chords at the start all of a sudden
these murky bass notes make their way in
eventually and then Nils sharpens these
waves of Basie drones with some higher
tones and all of a sudden these
slow-moving waves of sense just thicken
up they get bigger they get wider
they're larger than life
they're monolithic and the song comes to
a climax on the song toilet brushes with
all of these very nimbly played piano
chords and notes cascading over one
another with a little bit of delay
sounds overlapping one another really
beautifully its tracks like this that
the playing is so intense it's so
muscular it's so in the moment it's hard
for me not to get wrapped up in the
track get lost in it the execution is
fast it's somewhat technical as well but
the music that is being played is sort
of simple immediate straightforward but
not so much that it feels dumbed down
every move that's made on this record
feels very purposeful even on the songs
that do sort of feel a little bit more
like wallpaper to me
overall spaces does have some really
amazing moments on it to the point where
I want to stay in tune with whatever
this guy is putting out next I liked a
majority of this album a lot but I
didn't love every track here and I
thought spaces in its entirety was a
little too long-winded but personally my
biggest issue is that I wish these
performances and sort of Nils aesthetic
in general was just a little more
idiosyncratic I mean the compositions
are fantastic the playing is great and
tracks on here like toilet brushes and
hammers do show a significant amount of
eccentricity but there is a considerable
amount of tracks on here that do go by
without much in the way of a unique or
interesting angle I'm feeling a decent
strong seven on this thing transition if
you've given this album listen what did
you think of it did you love it did you
hate it why what do you think I should
review next and that's about it
Fantana spaces playing forever
